question.text: What is incorrect about the resting state of neuron?

options.text: High concentration of  <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math>  and negatively charged proteins and low concentration of  <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math>  in axoplasm.
Axonal membrane is nearly impermeable to  <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> .
Axonal membrane is more permeable to  <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> .
Outer surface of axon is negatively charged.

solution.text:
During resting state of neuron, axonal membrane is 

A. More permeable to K+.
B. Nearly Impermeable to Na+.
C. Impermeable to negatively charged proteins present in the axoplasm.

- The high concentration of K+ and negatively charged proteins and low concentration of Na+ in axoplasm.

- In contrast, the fluid outside the axon contains a low concentration of K+, a high concentration of Na+ and thus form a concentration gradient.

- These ionic gradients across the resting membrane are maintained by the Na–K pump which actively transports 3Na+ outwards for 2K+ into the cell.

- The outer surface of the axonal membrane is positively charged. The inner surface of axonal membrane is negatively charged.

- The axonal membrane is polarised and the potential difference is known as resting potential.
